Rhonda was brilliant and funny, a proud Mom and wife, a talented singer who sang at my gubernatorial inauguration, a West Point educated Army officer and a faith-filled spirit.

Today, as I was in the floor fighting for voting rights, I received word that a dear friend Rhonda Harmon died of leukemia. She was my law partner and we worked together fighting housing discrimination.

If not after the Supreme Court cuts the heart out of the Voting Right Act ‚Äì then when? 

If not after an avalanche of state legislation carving back voting rights ‚Äì then when?

I believe it will be the most important week of my Senate career.
And we‚Äôll grapple with a fundamental question‚Äîwhat is more important, acting to protect our democracy or adhering to outdated Senate rules that have often been changed over time by both parties?
I will discuss how Virginians in the 1950‚Äôs and 60‚Äôs holding the seat I now occupy used the filibuster to push Massive Resistance to civil rights laws.
And we‚Äôll discuss Senate rules, including the filibuster and its sad history of being used to block civil rights laws.
We‚Äôll discuss how our laws will require minimum standards for voting in federal elections, non-partisan redistricting in Congressional races, transparency of all campaign contributions.
We will dig into the coordinated assault on voting‚Äîthe attack of January 6 and efforts in many states to restrict voting and undermine electoral integrity.
We are scrapping our traditional MLK recess to have this debate. So appropriate.

Up until now, Republicans have blocked our ability to even consider voting rights‚Äîessentially a ‚Äúgag rule‚Äù on this topic. But we have found a path to begin debate on the Freedom to Vote Act and John Lewis Voting Rights Advancement Act even over Republican opposition.
Beginning Tuesday, the Senate will proceed to consider voting rights legislation for the first time in my Senate career.

Just like we responded to violence against John Lewis on Bloody Sunday and disenfranchisement with the Voting Rights Act, we need to respond to the violent attack on January 6 and disenfranchisement efforts across the country with the #FTVA and #JLVRAA.
It was an honor to meet with @OfficialMLK3 and Arndrea Waters King. We are all agreed: It‚Äôs time to reform Senate rules and pass comprehensive voting rights legislation. https://t.co/vqfVi9n0xs

The best way to overcome that and protect our democracy is by passing comprehensive voting rights legislation like my Freedom to Vote Act and the John Lewis Voting Rights Advancement Act.
They might not have been storming the Capitol on January 6, but Republican officials are using the same ‚Äòbig lie‚Äô to justify disenfranchising our fellow Americans.

Certain states with Republican governors and legislatures have used that same lie to restrict voting access, disempower nonpartisan election officials, and even threaten jail time for Americans who help their neighbors vote.
Unchallenged evil spreads like a virus. Trump‚Äôs ‚Äòbig lie‚Äô animated the attack on January 6 and has been spreading through our democracy and corroding it since then.

January 6 made clear that we must ensure that all Americans have the freedom to vote without obstacles or intimidation. That is what the Freedom to Vote Act does. The Senate must rise to the occasion and pass it.

I‚Äôm thrilled the House has passed the Build Back Better bill. Infrastructure doesn't build itself‚Äîyou've got to have a well-trained workforce and a system that enables them to go to work, like affordable child care. This legislation will do enormous good for America's future!

Some call it the Build Back Better bill. Some call it the reconciliation bill. I call it the education and workforce bill‚Äîto me, that's what this legislation is all about. It's an investment in America's workers, America's economy, and America's global success.

We‚Äôve heard again and again from voters: We gave you the majority, please act on it. 

I spoke on the Senate floor today to celebrate yesterday's infrastructure bill accomplishment‚Äîbut also to say we MUST pass the #BuildBackBetter bill. Americans want it, and they deserve it.

The impacts of this landmark bill will be felt in Virginia for generations to come. Billions for roads and bridges, rail, trails, climate resiliency, broadband, energy grid modernization, public transit, and so much more in our Commonwealth. Today is only the beginning!

So proud to have worked on this historic legislation‚Äîthe nation‚Äôs biggest commitment to infrastructure since the Interstate Highway system initiative in the Eisenhower Administration. Lin and Jinks have been the key inspiration for my wife Anne‚Äôs public service career.

Lin was also a magnificent grandfather. I will always be thankful for his role in my life.
